docs.snippet: After reading Kevin Kelly's article, I felt the need to go and look at my book collection, most of which I inherited from my mother. I handled each book gently, since they are all now quite frail. My mother's books are more than personal mementos....
docs.lead_paragraph: After reading Kevin Kelly's article, I felt the need to go and look at my book collection, most of which I inherited from my mother. I handled each book gently, since they are all now quite frail. My mother's books are more than personal mementos. They are a reminder that some things cannot, and should not, be replaced. I use the Internet all the time and I think it's fantastic -- for research, not for reading. I mean really reading. A book may look ''inert,'' but there's nothing inert about what happens when I shut off the PC and the TV, and begin to read. There is an intimacy to holding this special possession in my hands that I cannot experience by looking at a plastic screen inside a metal box. I applaud the dazzling advances in research that the Internet has brought and will continue to bring. And yet I will, at the end of every day, curl up with a good book, not a good computer. Clare Higgins Gloucester, Mass.
docs.abstract: Clare Higgins letter comments on May 14 article on Google's plans for digitized universal library

docs.snippet: The option to see all the information connected to a main idea or source might actually discourage creative thinking and might produce lazy scholars (Kevin Kelly, May 14). Those searching for information may not be inspired to draw parallels betwe...
docs.lead_paragraph: The option to see all the information connected to a main idea or source might actually discourage creative thinking and might produce lazy scholars (Kevin Kelly, May 14). Those searching for information may not be inspired to draw parallels between obscure ideas or topics, and may be less inclined to make their own judgments about original material. The answers will become too available, and as a result, the educational journey of research may become obsolete. Randi Brown New York
docs.abstract: Randi Brown letter comments on May 14 article on Google's plans for digitized universal library

docs.snippet: I found it surprising that nowhere in the discussion of a digitized universal library was there mention of Jorge Luis Borges's ''Library of Babel.'' In 1941, Borges posited the existence of an endless library (otherwise known as the universe) that...
docs.lead_paragraph: I found it surprising that nowhere in the discussion of a digitized universal library was there mention of Jorge Luis Borges's ''Library of Babel.'' In 1941, Borges posited the existence of an endless library (otherwise known as the universe) that was made up of infinite hexagonal galleries of books, containing everything ever written, including all that has ever been conceived of having been written. While Borges feared the human species might be on the verge of extinction, he did believe that ''the Library -- enlightened, solitary, infinite, perfectly unmoving, armed with precious volumes, pointless, incorruptible, and secret -- will endure.'' Robby Ameen New York
docs.abstract: Robby Ameen letter comments on May 14 article on Google's plans for digitized universal library

docs.snippet: The ability to decompose and rearrange narrativetexts may be useful in ''sound-bite scholarship'' and intellectual scrapbooking. But the digital noise created by all the communal editing and footnoting may drown out any thoughtful conversation bet...
docs.lead_paragraph: The ability to decompose and rearrange narrativetexts may be useful in ''sound-bite scholarship'' and intellectual scrapbooking. But the digital noise created by all the communal editing and footnoting may drown out any thoughtful conversation between reader and author.A library of self-contained texts, immune from indiscriminate tampering, has been, is and will continue to be our best hope for moral, ethical and intellectual evolution. Michael C. Lang New York
docs.abstract: Michael C Lang letter comments on May 14 article on Google's plans for digitized universal library

docs.snippet: FED CHAIRMAN'S WARNING -- Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that recent inflation trends were ''unwelcome developments,'' indicating that he was far less worried about signs of weaker economic growth than about the danger of...
docs.lead_paragraph: FED CHAIRMAN'S WARNING -- Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that recent inflation trends were ''unwelcome developments,'' indicating that he was far less worried about signs of weaker economic growth than about the danger of higher prices. [Page C1.] STOCKS RETREAT -- Share prices had their biggest loss since January after remarks by the Federal Reserve chairman. The Dow average retreated 199.15 points, or 1.8 percent, to 11,048.72. [C10.] GOOGLE SPREADSHEETS -- Stepping up its attack on Microsoft's core business, Google plans to make available a test version of a Web-based spreadsheet program intended to make it simple to edit and share lists and numeric data online. [C1.] WINDOW ON A CASE -- Widely watched at the time, a lawsuit against Oxford Health Plans that was settled in 2003 has taken on new import in light of admissions by a plaintiff and prosecutors' charges against the law firm Milberg Weiss. [A1.] DRUG TO RETURN -- Federal regulators agreed to let the multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri return to the market, despite its risk of causing a fatal brain disease. A program is to closely monitor the drug's use. Tysabri, pulled early last year after only three months on the market, is marketed by Biogen Idec of the United States and Elan of Ireland. [C1.] RESISTANCE TO MODIFIED CROPS -- Greece and a few other European Union countries that have banned genetically modified crops are on the front lines of a war over the future of modified food in Europe. [C1.] STOP-AND-GO DINING -- Family-style restaurants like Applebee's and Outback Steakhouse are offering curbside dining, where customers can have meals delivered to their cars as they sit idling outside the restaurant. The new offering is a hit. [C1.] A.C.L.U. ASKS FOR MERGER DELAY -- The American Civil Liberties Union asked the Federal Communications Commission to withhold approval of AT&T's acquisition of BellSouth until it reviews allegations that the companies gave customer records to the government without warrants. [C3.] JAPANESE 'RAIDER' ARRESTED -- Yoshiaki Murakami, a self-proclaimed corporate raider who struck fear into Japan's insider-run boardrooms, was arrested on suspicion of insider trading. Tokyo prosecutors said Mr. Murakami, left, violated securities laws by buying shares of a radio station after hearing directly from the Internet portal Livedoor that it was buying shares. [C6.] G.M. MEETING -- Though General Motors lost $10.6 billion last year and faces a particularly uncertain future, its chief executive, Rick Wagoner, will undoubtedly find plenty of good news to talk about at today's annual shareholders' meeting in Wilmington, Del. [C3.] DEAL IN REAL ESTATE -- Brookfield Properties, one of the largest landlords in Manhattan, and the Blackstone Group, a private equity firm, said they had agreed to acquire the Trizec real estate company for $4.8 billion. [C3.] WIND POWER -- With wind power projects in the midst of a growth spurt in many parts of the country, local activists want to slow them down. They are finding themselves increasingly out of step with the priorities of the broader environmental movement. [A18.] PIXELS VS. PRINT -- In the matchup between the print and online versions of newspapers, signs of the Internet's ascendancy are growing stronger. The latest is a survey that found online ad spending surged 35 percent in the first three months of 2006. Advertising. [C3.] CHINA CARRIERS NEAR MERGER -- After two years of talks, Cathay Pacific Airways is on the verge of taking full control of Dragonair to become the main foreign carrier serving China, people close to the talks said. [C7.] REFCO SETTLEMENT -- An Austrian bank, Bawag PSK, will pay at least $675 million to avoid prosecution and to settle bankruptcy claims after admitting a role in the collapse of the brokerage firm Refco. [C3.] RUSSIAN I.P.O.'S -- Setbacks in some Russian initial public offerings give the appearance of a wholesale retrenchment, rather than a retreat by one or two troubled companies. [C4.] GREENSPAN MEMOIR -- Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, has chosen Peter Petre, a senior editor at large at Fortune magazine, as a collaborator for his memoir. The book is to be published by Penguin Press in fall 2007. [E1.] ONLINE A DAY AT BELMONT -- Harry Hurt III, the writer of the Executive Pursuits column, spends a day at the races. A slide show can be found at nytimes.com/business. THE GOODS -- A lifelong fan of ''alternative lighting,'' a frustrated artist turns lingerie into lampshades. A report is at nytimes.com/business/yourmoney. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.

docs.snippet: I chuckled as I read the letters (May 28) criticizing Kevin Kelly's article (May 14) on the coming revolution in distributing book content online. The critics are clearly bedfellows in print: writers, publishers a museum curator. The same kind of ...
docs.lead_paragraph: I chuckled as I read the letters (May 28) criticizing Kevin Kelly's article (May 14) on the coming revolution in distributing book content online. The critics are clearly bedfellows in print: writers, publishers a museum curator. The same kind of entrenched folks no doubt resisted the digital transformation of library card catalogs a few years ago. And long before that, blacksmiths and wagonmakers were similarly disposed against the railroaders. All disruptive technologies have their momentary detractors. What an exciting time we readers live in. Sheldon Peck Waban, Mass.
docs.abstract: Sheldon Peck letter comments on May 28 letters commenting on May 14 article about Google's plans for digitized universal library

docs.snippet: SEASON OPENER    The News -- The 2006 Congressional campaign season got under way early, with a special election for a House seat in San Diego.    Behind the News -- Republicans held on to the seat, which was left vacant when Randy Cunningham resi...
docs.lead_paragraph: SEASON OPENER The News -- The 2006 Congressional campaign season got under way early, with a special election for a House seat in San Diego. Behind the News -- Republicans held on to the seat, which was left vacant when Randy Cunningham resigned after pleading guilty in a corruption scandal. But the thin victory margin of the winner, Brian P. Bilbray, was a sign that the party may be in for difficult times in more competitive districts. Campaigns were already in full swing in some of those districts, long before the traditional Labor Day start of the election season. CYBER-RIVALRY The News -- Google unveiled a new online spreadsheet program, the latest volley in its attacks against its rival Microsoft. Behind the News -- The free program, Google Spreadsheets, is designed to allow multiple users to work on a spreadsheet simultaneously. But more important, perhaps, is that it can read files created in Microsoft's popular program Excel. So it's another step in Google's efforts to make inroads on Microsoft's core business, desktop programs. Microsoft has countered in recent years by expanding its Web offerings. BOOMTOWN The News -- Construction contractors for the Freedom Tower announced they would begin work on the foundation by blasting away bedrock. Behind the News -- While the thought of more explosions at the World Trade Center site might be chilling to residents and workers in Lower Manhattan, those in charge of the project said that the detonations, to be carried out over two months, would hardly be noticeable. Blasting, they added, would produce far less dust and din than the constant pounding of an alternative method, hydraulic rams attached to backhoes. M-M-MEMORIES The News -- Barbra Streisand announced she would perform in 20 cities this fall, her first concert tour in a dozen years. Behind the News -- Since Ms. Streisand, 64, never really retired, it's not a comeback tour. A more accurate description might be ''marathon fund-raising event.'' The singer, who has long used her concerts to raise money for political causes, said she would donate proceeds this time to educational, environmental and women's health groups. PLAYTIME The News -- The 32-team World Cup soccer tournament got under way in Germany with the opening match in Munich. Behind the News -- Concerns about how the monthlong event might be affected by racist fans, bribable referees, an influx of prostitutes and even the shape of the ball dominated much of the discussion in the weeks leading up to it. Most of the worries melted away as play began, although German and English fans had to be separated by police officers in Frankfut. In the opener, Germany defeated Costa Rica, 4-2.

headline.main: Hiding in Plain Sight, Google Seeks More Power

byline.original: By JOHN MARKOFF and SAUL HANSELL

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    Bush, in Baghdad, Urges Iraqis to Pull Together  President Bush used a surprise visit to Baghdad to say that the time had come for Iraqis to pull together to save the faltering American-sponsored democracy there.    A1    ...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Bush, in Baghdad, Urges Iraqis to Pull Together President Bush used a surprise visit to Baghdad to say that the time had come for Iraqis to pull together to save the faltering American-sponsored democracy there. A1 Insurgents unleashed a volley of bombings across the northern oil city of Kirkuk, killing more than two dozen Iraqis. A15 In one of the first tallies of Iraqis fleeing Iraq since the American-led invasion, the United States Committee for Refugees and Immigrants counted 644,500 Iraqi refugees in Syria and Jordan in 2005. A15 Israeli Strike Kills More Civilians Eight Palestinian civilians were killed and more than 40 wounded by an Israeli missile strike on Islamic militants. Israel's defense minister said an investigation into the earlier death of a family showed that Israel was not to blame. A1 Global Views on U.S. Are Dim The global image of America has slipped further, even among people in some countries closely allied with the United States, according to a survey done in 15 nations this spring by the Pew Research Center. A8 Indonesia to Release Cleric A radical Islamic cleric, whom the Bush administration has portrayed as an important operative for Al Qaeda in Southeast Asia, was scheduled to walk out of prison after serving just over a year for criminal conspiracy, his lawyers and Indonesian officials said. A10 Costly Indonesian Earthquake The Indonesian government said more than $3 billion would be needed for reconstruction because of the May 27 earthquake, far more than originally estimated. A9 Muslim Shot Without Warning A 23-year-old Muslim man who was shot and wounded in London during what the police have described as a counterterrorism operation said the officers had not identified themselves and had given no warning before opening fire at close range. A10 NATIONAL A16-21 No Charges Against Rove In the C.I.A. Leak Case The decision by a special prosecutor not to bring charges against Karl Rove in the C.I.A. leak case followed months of intense behind-the-scenes maneuvering between the prosecutor, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, and Mr. Rove's lawyer, according to lawyers in the case. A1 Many Still in FEMA Trailers Tens of thousands of people continue to live crammed in FEMA trailers, greeting this year's hurricane season the same way they said goodbye to the last one. A1 The House of Representatives approved a $94.5 billion emergency spending bill to provide more money for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan and to finance the recovery of Gulf Coast states battered by hurricanes last year. A21 Baptists Have New President The nation's 16 million Southern Baptists have a new president, Dr. Frank S. Page, elected in an upset victory that he said marked a turning point for a church that has grown increasingly conservative. A18 Storm Posed No Serious Threat Tropical Storm Alberto weakened before hitting the Florida Gulf Coast with heavy rain and high winds, but it did not pose the threat forecasters had feared. A20 KFC Sued by Nutrition Group A nutrition advocacy group sued KFC to get it to stop using partially hydrogenated oils, a key ingredient of its fried chicken. The oils contain trans fats, which scientists consider the most unhealthful of all fats. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH Prozac Ineffective for Anorexia A widely used treatment for anorexia nervosa, the antidepressant Prozac, works no better than dummy pills in preventing recurrence of the eating disorder in young women who have recovered from it, researchers are reporting. A21 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Texas Tourist Stabbed By Stranger on the Subway A man sitting in a subway car on the Upper West Side suddenly stood up, crossed the aisle and repeatedly thrust a knife into the chest of a 21-year-old tourist from Texas riding with a female friend, critically wounding him, the police said. A1 Giuliani Faults Energy Policy Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, challenging fellow Republicans in Washington, said that the Bush administration lacked an energy policy and that greater reliance on nuclear power, ethanol-based fuels and hybrid vehicles was more realistic than President Bush's goal of independence from foreign energy sources. B1 Tower May Hinge on Leases A top official of the Port Authority cast new doubt on whether the Freedom Tower's steel frame would ever rise above street level at ground zero. The 1,776-foot tower would have to be reconsidered if state officials fail to obtain leases for 1 million square feet from federal agencies by September, the official said. B3 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-7 Heat Takes Game 3 Miami's Dwyane Wade scored 42 points and lead the Heat to a 98-96 come-from-behind victory over the Dallas Mavericks in Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals. Miami trails 2-1 in the best-of-seven series. D1 ARTS E1-10 PBS Looks to a Digital Future Staking its future in the digital media world, the Public Broadcasting Service has created a new post of chief content officer and named a public broadcasting executive with extensive digital experience to fill the job. John Boland, 57, is currently the executive vice president and chief content officer at KQED Public Broadcasting in San Francisco. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Digital Giants Square Off The land around the Columbia River along the Oregon-Washington border, at the intersection of cheap electricity and accessible data networking, is the backdrop for a billion-dollar face-off among Google, Microsoft and Yahoo that will determine Internet dominance for years to come. A1 Global Stocks Tumble Around the world, waves of selling sent stocks and commodities tumbling. C1 Goldman Profits Soar Goldman Sachs said it more than doubled its second-quarter profit from a year ago. However, the firm's stock suffered from concerns that recent market weakness would continue and form a seasonal summer slowdown in brokerage activity. C1 Tribune Trusts Disagree Two towering figures in 20th century newspaper publishing created distinctive trusts to safeguard the papers they built and the causes they championed. Now the two trusts -- both shareholders in the Tribune Company -- differ on a plan to revive the company's slumping shares. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Too soon to cheer in Baghdad; worse than nothing; wrenching changes on the line; Adam Cohen on whether a 15-year-old with a laptop could be the new campaign media guru. Column: Thomas L. Friedman. Crossword E6 TV Listings E9 Obituaries B8 Weather D8

docs.snippet: GOOGLE'S BIG PLANS -- On the banks of the windswept Columbia River in Oregon, Google is working on a secret weapon in its quest to dominate the next generation of Internet computing: a computing center as big as two football fields. [Page A1.]    ...
docs.lead_paragraph: GOOGLE'S BIG PLANS -- On the banks of the windswept Columbia River in Oregon, Google is working on a secret weapon in its quest to dominate the next generation of Internet computing: a computing center as big as two football fields. [Page A1.] GOLDMAN PROFIT LEAPS -- Goldman Sachs said it more than doubled its second-quarter profit from a year ago, with strong results in each of its divisions. The bank reported net income for the second quarter of $2.31 billion, or $4.78 a share. Market Place. [C1.] MARKETS STRUCK BY SELLING -- Waves of selling, described by some analysts as panicked, sent stocks and commodities tumbling around the world. The worst declines were in Asia. [C1.] WHOLESALE PRICES -- Higher prices at the manufacturing level helped push overall prices of wholesale goods higher in May, the Labor Department reported. At the same time, the government said that retail sales were essentially flat. [C3.] DUELING LEGACIES -- Two trusts representing the legacies of Harry Chandler and Col. Robert R. McCormick have taken starkly different views of the plan by the Tribune Company's management to revive the media giant's slumping shares [C1.] SHOWDOWN OVER OIL -Danny Williams, premier of Newfoundland and Labrador, is a multimillionaire and a member of the Conservative Party of Canada. But in his fight with Big Oil over a field's development, he is being compared to Venezuela's president, Hugo Chávez. [C1.] EBAY-SKYPE LINK -- EBay said that sellers on its auction site will soon be able to add a link to their listings that will let potential buyers reach them through Skype, the Internet phone service that eBay bought last year. The announcement comes nine months after eBay raised eyebrows by spending $2.6 billion for Skype, a European start-up that at the time had just $60 million in sales. [C5.] U.A.W. FINANCES RECRUITMENT -- The United Automobile Workers union has voted to use part of its $914 million strike fund to pay for recruitment of new members. [C3.] SUIT TAKES AIM AT FAT -- A nutrition advocacy group, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, has sued KFC to stop its use of a key ingredient of its fried chicken -- partly hydrogenated oils containing trans fat, which scientists consider the most unhealthy fat. [A16.] BP TO FINANCE BIOFUELS PROGRAM -- BP is planning to spend $500 million over the next 10 years to finance major work on biofuels. The energy giant is in talks with several universities in the United States and Britain as possible sites for the research center. BP's chief executive, Lord Browne, above, is expected to formally announce the program in London today. [C9.] ENRON SETTLEMENT -- Two small utilities are set to pay more than $50 million to Enron for electricity that they agreed to buy but that Enron will never deliver, under a settlement that raises larger issues. [C3.] PROZAC FOR ANOREXIA -- One of the most widely used treatments for anorexia nervosa, the antidepressant Prozac, works no better than dummy pills in preventing recurrence of the disorder in young women who have recovered from it, researchers are reporting. [A21.] PBS NAMES CONTENT CHIEF -- Staking its future in digital media, the Public Broadcasting Service has created a new post of chief content officer and named a public broadcasting executive with extensive digital experience to fill the job. [E1.] DELAY IN JET DELIVERIES -- Airbus said it would produce only 9 of its giant new A380 jets next year, not the 25 planned, because of numerous design changes. [C3.] FACE TO FACE -- The public face-off between Mittal Steel and Arcelor, rival steel giants, may soften a bit as a result of a meeting in Brussels. There, they were expected to discuss a potential merger. [C9.] DRUG MAKER'S SUIT -- The German drug and chemicals company Bayer filed suit in a New York court to stop a German rival, Merck, from voting its recently acquired stake in Schering. Bayer has bid 16.5 billion euros, or $20.8 billion, for Schering. [C9.] TEACHERS' UNION SETTLES -- A powerful teachers' union agreed to pay $100,000 as part of a settlement with the office of the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer. The union, the New York State United Teachers, was paid $3 million a year by the Dutch financial services firm ING, and in return it endorsed ING's retirement products to its more than 500,000 members. [B5.$) ONLINE CHINA'S COAL CRISIS --The Times's David Barboza describes how China's coal industry is creating an environmental and health care crisis. See video at www.nytimes.com/worldbusiness. AMAZONIAN DRUG HOPES -- The Brazilian government believes an Amazonian remedy holds promise for the global pharmaceutical industry. See an audio slide show at www.nytimes.com/worldbusiness. INVESTOR TOOLS -- Information on all United States stocks, and bonds, mutual funds, commodities and foreign stocks, as well as analysis of industry sectors and stock indexes can be found at nytimes.com/business. HOW MUCH HOUSE CAN YOU BUY? -- Though the real estate market appears to state otherwise, over the last 20 years it has become more affordable to buy a house in many parts of the country. Find out if this is the case in your area at www.nytimes.com/realestate/owning.

docs.abstract: It's no surprise that the real-estate market is being affected by the gigantic computerplex being built by Google in The Dalles, Ore. The project, according to our Page 1 story, has "caused local real estate prices to jump 40 percent and is expected to create 60 to 200 permanent jobs in a town of 12,000 [...]

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''When a Risqué Online Persona Undermines a Chance for a Job'' (front page, June 11):     Certainly each individual is responsible for his or her own level of self-disclosure on the Internet. But it would well serve the comp...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''When a Risqué Online Persona Undermines a Chance for a Job'' (front page, June 11): Certainly each individual is responsible for his or her own level of self-disclosure on the Internet. But it would well serve the companies that take the time to investigate their job applicants' online presence to remember that while each individual is unique, each name is not.
docs.abstract: Two letters respond to June 11 article about companies that are investigating their job applicants' online presence; Amanda Doster holds that companies should remember that while each individual is unique, each name is not; Alia Husain maintains that there is bias against young people in job market

docs.snippet: Some thought Google might buy Chinese rival Baidu.com. It has done just the opposite....
docs.lead_paragraph: As recently as April, some analysts thought Google might be interested in buying Baidu.com, the undisputed leader of Internet search in China. But Google has apparently done just the opposite. Regulatory filings show that the United States-based company has recently sold its entire stake in Baidu, which amounted to about 2 percent of Baidu's equity. Google's comments on the transaction only reinforced the notion that it does not plan to buy its way into the Chinese market.

headline.main: Google Dumps Stake in a Chinese Rival

docs.abstract: Some thought Google might buy Chinese rival Baidu.com. It has done just the opposite.

headline.main: Vuitton Bags Court Decision Against Google

docs.abstract: Louis Vuitton, the luxury goods manufacturer, won another round Wednesday in its court battle with the search engine Google to eliminate online ads of competitors or counterfeiters that show up in searches for the well-known French brand. A Paris appeals court issued a ruling that found Google engaged in trademark counterfeiting, a decision that the [...]

docs.snippet: GOOGLE PAYMENT SERVICE Google is introducing a service that will let users make purchases from online stores using payment and shipping information they keep on file with Google. [Page C1.]    ACCUSATIONS AGAINST BP Federal regulators charged that...
docs.lead_paragraph: GOOGLE PAYMENT SERVICE Google is introducing a service that will let users make purchases from online stores using payment and shipping information they keep on file with Google. [Page C1.] ACCUSATIONS AGAINST BP Federal regulators charged that BP manipulated the price of propane two years ago by cornering the market through its dominant position, pushing up heating costs for millions at the peak of winter demand. [C1.] MUSICAL BIDDING WAR Years of jockeying to combine two of the world's biggest music companies, the EMI Group and the Warner Music Group, has escalated with the two now bidding to take over one another. EMI said yesterday that it had raised its recent bid for Warner Music to $31 a share, or about $4.6 billion. Warner then turned the tables and extended an offer for EMI of roughly $4.6 billion, to be financed mainly by debt. EMI dismissed the bid as ''wholly unacceptable.'' [C1.] SUMMER OF CAR DEALS American car shoppers have learned that summer is the season of big discounts, and this year is shaping up no differently, with some discounts amounting to savings of 20 percent or more. [C1.] HEDGE FUND TESTIMONY A former investigator for the Securities and Exchange Commission told Congress on Wednesday how senior S.E.C. officials gave in to what he described as political pressure and stopped his investigation of suspected insider trading by a prominent hedge fund. [C3.] AD FORECAST LOWERED A leading forecaster of advertising spending has again lowered his estimate for growth in the United States in 2006. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C13.] NEW CHAIRMAN AT DISNEY The Walt Disney Company announced that John E. Pepper Jr., a former Procter & Gamble chief executive who joined Disney's board early this year, had been appointed non-executive chairman. [C13.] STOCKS ADVANCE The Dow Jones industrial average gained 48.82 points to finish at 10,973.56. The Standard & Poor's 500 added 6.80 points to end at 1,246. The Nasdaq advanced 11.59 points to close at 2,111.84. [C15.] INSURANCE WOES IN FLORIDA Many Florida residents are scouring for homeowners' insurance after two ferocious hurricane seasons and struggling to pay for what they find. [A16.] F.A.A. CUTS The Federal Aviation Administration, in a three-pronged approach to cutting its costs, is halting many personnel transfers in its air traffic system, reducing the staffing levels for air traffic controllers and evaluating layoffs of weather forecasters. [A16.] MALARIA FIGHT Wielding a combination of new medicines, better bed nets, old-fashioned pesticides and data analysis, the mining company Billiton and its partners in business and government have made major inroads in the fight against malaria in Mozambique. [A1.] ORTHOPEDIC PRICING For years, makers of artificial hips and other orthopedic devices have benefited from their pricing power. But that may not last much longer. [C4.] MAINE'S STRUGGLING ECONOMY Maine was the only state besides Louisiana to see a decline in economic activity last year, according to a new Federal Reserve study. [A17.] BATTLE FOR GAZPROM SPOT Two outsiders are trying to join Gazprom's board, which has been a tight combination of government ministers and well-heeled businessmen for most of its 15-year existence. [C9.] RUSSIA'S NUCLEAR REVAMPING Russia has unveiled details of a plan to reorganize the country's myriad nuclear power plants, agencies, institutes and departments into a single state company modeled on Gazprom. Underscoring the source of its economic inspiration, the name of the enterprise is likely to be Atomprom, Sergei V. Kiriyenko, above, the director of the Atomic Energy Agency, said. [C9.] ENTER THE AVON MAN The Avon lady isn't what she used to be. For one, she isn't always a woman. [G1.] RADAR IS REVIVED Radar, the pop-culture glossy publication, is being resurrected. [C6.] INDIANA WINS HONDA PLANT Indiana won the race to land a Honda assembly plant. [C4.] ONLINE ONLINE: DEALBOOK A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHY Digital scrapbooking, watching whales in high-def and tips from the pros can be found at nytimes.com/technology. A SOCIALITE IN THE CROWD Designers are recruiting socialites for ads, hoping to sprinkle status on handbags. A report is at nytimes.com/style. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. ANADARKO PETROLEUM, which agreed last week to buy Kerr-McGee and Western Gas Resources, plans to sell its Canadian subsidiary and use the proceeds to repay debt. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) MICHAEL JACKSON is moving to Europe, has fired his business managers and has hired a New York-based firm. He has been living in Bahrain since he was acquitted of child molestation charges a year ago. (ASSOCIATED PRESS) LINEAR TECHNOLOGY, Macrovision and Asyst Technologies said a United States attorney's office is seeking information related to stock option grants. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)
